00030 // #include "qassert.h"
00031 // Q_DEFINE_THIS_MODULE(qf_tick)

00036 
00037 //............................................................................
00038 void QF::tick(void) {                                            // see NOTE01
00039     QF_INT_LOCK_KEY_
00040     QF_INT_LOCK_();
00041 
00042     QS_BEGIN_NOLOCK_(QS_QF_TICK, (void *)0, (void *)0)
00043         QS_TEC_(++QS::tickCtr_);                           // the tick counter
00044     QS_END_NOLOCK_()
00045 
00046     QTimeEvt *t = QF_timeEvtListHead_;
00047     while (t != (QTimeEvt *)0) {
00048         --t->m_ctr;
00049         if (t->m_ctr == (QTimeEvtCtr)0) {  // is the time evt about to expire?
00050             if (t->m_interval != (QTimeEvtCtr)0) {//is it a periodic time evt?
00051                 t->m_ctr = t->m_interval;                // rearm the time evt
00052             }
00053             else {   // one-shot time evt, disarm by removing it from the list
00054                 if (t == QF_timeEvtListHead_) {
00055                     QF_timeEvtListHead_ = t->m_next;
00056                 }
00057                 else {
00058                     if (t->m_next != (QTimeEvt *)0) {// not the last time evt?
00059                         t->m_next->m_prev = t->m_prev;
00060                     }
00061                     t->m_prev->m_next = t->m_next;
00062                 }
00063                 t->m_prev = (QTimeEvt *)0;     // mark the time event disarmed
00064 
00065                 QS_BEGIN_NOLOCK_(QS_QF_TIMEEVT_AUTO_DISARM, QS::teObj_, t)
00066                     QS_OBJ_(t);                      // this time event object
00067                     QS_OBJ_(t->m_act);                     // the active object
00068                 QS_END_NOLOCK_()
00069             }
00070 
00071             QS_BEGIN_NOLOCK_(QS_QF_TIMEEVT_POST, QS::teObj_, t)
00072                 QS_TIME_();                                       // timestamp
00073                 QS_OBJ_(t);                           // the time event object
00074                 QS_SIG_(t->sig);              // the signal of this time event
00075                 QS_OBJ_(t->m_act);                        // the active object
00076             QS_END_NOLOCK_()
00077 
00078             QF_INT_UNLOCK_();   // unlock interrupts before calling QF service
00079 
00080                   // postFIFO() asserts internally that the event was accepted
00081             t->m_act->postFIFO(t);
00082         }
00083         else {
00084             QF_INT_UNLOCK_();
00085             static uint8_t volatile dummy;
00086             dummy = (uint8_t)0;      // execute a few instructions, see NOTE02
00087         }
00088 
00089         QF_INT_LOCK_();           // lock interrupts again to advance the link
00090         t = t->m_next;
00091     }
00092     QF_INT_UNLOCK_();
00093 }
00094 
00096 // NOTE01:
00097 // QF::tick() must always run to completion and never preempt itself.
00098 // In particular, if QF::tick() runs in an ISR, the ISR is not allowed to
00099 // preempt itself. Also, QF::tick() should not be called from two different
00100 // ISRs, which potentially could preempt each other.
00101 //
00102 // NOTE02:
00103 // On many CPUs, the interrupt unlocking takes only effect on the next
00104 // machine instruction, which happens to be here another interrupt lock.
00105 // The assignment of a volatile variable requires a few instructions, which
00106 // the compiler cannot optimize away. This ensures that the interrupts get
00107 // actually unlocked, so that the interrupt latency stays low.
00108 //
